examples.input_text: Write me example of using blobs?
examples.output_text_a:
To use BLOBs in CrateDB, you first need to create a BLOB table using the Crate Shell. This table must be created before adding any BLOBs. Here is an example SQL statement to create a BLOB table:

```
sh$ crash -c "create blob table myblobs clustered into 3 shards with (number_of_replicas=1)"
```

Once the BLOB table is created, you can upload a BLOB by issuing a PUT request. Here is an example of uploading a BLOB:

```
sh$ curl -isSX PUT '127.0.0.1:4200/_blobs/myblobs/4a756ca07e9487f482465a99e8286abc86ba4dc7' -d 'contents'
```

For more information on using BLOBs in CrateDB, you can refer to the [official documentation](https://cratedb.com/blog/using-crate-as-a-blobstore).
examples.output_text_b:
To upload a blob, you can issue a PUT request using a tool like curl. Here is an example:

```
sh$ curl -isSX PUT '127.0.0.1:4200/_blobs/myblobs/4a756ca07e9487f482465a99e8286abc86ba4dc7' -d 'contents' HTTP/1.1
```

You can find more information on using Crate as a blobstore [here](https://cratedb.com/blog/using-crate-as-a-blobstore).

examples.input_text: How to use BLOB store in CrateDB? and what are the benefits?
examples.output_text_a:
To use BLOB store in CrateDB, you can store binary large objects such as pictures, videos, or large unstructured files in a table that will be automatically sharded and replicated across your cluster. This ensures optimal distribution and efficient replication of these files across multiple nodes in a cluster. 

The benefits of using CrateDB for BLOB storage include:
- Automatic sharding and replication, saving datastore administration work
- Consistent replication and sharding rules for both BLOBs and other data
- Integration of BLOBs into CrateDB with a dedicated BLOB table for effective distribution across nodes
- Scalability and improved performance through sharding and replication of BLOBs just like regular data

Sources:
- [CrateDB Blob Data Features](https://cratedb.com/product/features/blob-data)
- [Using Crate as a Blobstore Blog](https://cratedb.com/blog/using-crate-as-a-blobstore)
examples.output_text_b:
To use BLOB store in CrateDB, you can store binary large objects (BLOBs) in a table which will be automatically sharded and replicated across the cluster. CrateDB treats BLOBs like regular data, ensuring their optimal distribution across multiple nodes in the cluster. 

Benefits of using BLOB store in CrateDB include:
- Efficient replication and sharding of BLOBs similar to regular data
- Simplified administration work due to automatic sharding and replication
- Integration of a dedicated BLOB table to distribute binaries effectively across nodes
- Improved scalability and performance by treating BLOBs like regular data

Sources:
- [Using Crate as a Blobstore](https://cratedb.com/blog/using-crate-as-a-blobstore)
- [CrateDB Features: Blob Data](https://cratedb.com/product/features/blob-data)

An IAM role is required, and an AWS guide provides instructions on how to create a policy using the CLI or AWS management console. Further, access to the snapshot in the S3 bucket needs to be restricted by setting specific policies. More information can be found [here](https://cratedb.com/docs/guide/install/cloud/aws/s3-setup.html).

More detailed information on how to restrict permissions can be found in the AWS policy examples and the links provided in the source documentation: [CrateDB AWS Permissions Restriction](https://cratedb.com/docs/guide/install/cloud/aws/s3-setup.html)

examples.input_text: How AWS marketplace works, and why I cannot see deployment in my account?
examples.output_text_a: To deploy a cluster on CrateDB Cloud using AWS Marketplace, you need to sign up via AWS Marketplace and have an AWS Marketplace account. The usage is billed directly by Amazon, not by Crate.io. It may take up to 10 minutes for the subscription to be confirmed and usable in the CrateDB Cloud console. If you cannot see the deployment in your account, you may need to unsubscribe from the AWS Marketplace offer by logging into your AWS Marketplace account and selecting Your Marketplace Software from the dropdown menu. For more information, you can refer to the source [here](https://cratedb.com/docs/cloud/en/latest/tutorials/deploy/marketplace/subscribe-aws.html#signup-aws-to-cluster) and [here](https://cratedb.com/docs/cloud/en/latest/howtos/delete-cluster.html).
examples.output_text_b:
To deploy a cluster on CrateDB Cloud via AWS Marketplace, you need to sign up for an AWS Marketplace account. Your hourly usage will be billed directly by Amazon, not by Crate.io. It can take up to 10 minutes for the subscription to be confirmed and usable in the CrateDB Cloud console. If you cannot see the deployment in your account, you may need to unsubscribe from the AWS Marketplace offer by logging into the AWS Marketplace website with the account used to subscribe to the offer and accessing Your Marketplace Software in the dropdown menu. 

Sources: 
- [CrateDB Cloud AWS Marketplace Tutorial](https://cratedb.com/docs/cloud/en/latest/tutorials/deploy/marketplace/subscribe-aws.html)
- [Deleting a Cluster via AWS Marketplace](https://cratedb.com/docs/cloud/en/latest/howtos/delete-cluster.html)

examples.input_text: What are edge regions and how to use them?
examples.output_text_a: Edge regions are components of a deployed Edge Region that need to be updated regularly to continue receiving new features, bugfixes, and security updates. To use them, users can upgrade their Edge Regions by following the instructions provided in the CrateDB documentation, which may involve creating custom regions, deploying clusters in combination with existing cloud providers, and configuring necessary storage classes. More information can be found [here](https://cratedb.com/docs/cloud/en/latest/tutorials/edge/introduction.html#edge-disclaimer).
examples.output_text_b: Edge regions are components of a deployed Edge Region that are not updated automatically. Users should update their Edge Regions regularly to continue getting new features, bugfixes, and security updates. To use them, users can create custom regions by filling out a name for the region and clicking on the "Create edge region" button in the Regions tab of the CrateDB Cloud Console. Additionally, users can deploy CrateDB Edge in combination with an existing cloud provider by choosing a cloud provider from the fields provided and clicking "Deploy cluster" in the Regions tab. To deploy a cluster in a custom region, users can provide a name for the custom region and click the "Create edge region" button. More information can be found [here](https://cratedb.com/docs/cloud/en/latest/tutorials/edge/introduction.html#edge-disclaimer).

examples.input_text: Write me example python code to use CrateDB?
examples.output_text_a:
To write example python code to use CrateDB, you can refer to the CrateDB Python driver documentation at [https://cratedb.com/connect/python](https://cratedb.com/connect/python). Additionally, you can explore the examples provided in the documentation at [https://cratedb.com/docs/python/en/latest/by-example/index.html#by-example](https://cratedb.com/docs/python/en/latest/by-example/index.html#by-example) which detail different ways to interact with CrateDB using Python. 

You can also check out the executable code examples maintained within the cratedb-examples repository, which demonstrate the use of the driver for various applications like a "guestbook" application. The documentation also includes code snippets on how to connect to CrateDB using pandas and how to load and export data. More details can be found at [https://cratedb.com/docs/python/en/latest/](https://cratedb.com/docs/python/en/latest/).

In summary, by referring to the official CrateDB Python driver documentation and the provided examples, you can easily write python code to interact with CrateDB.
examples.output_text_b:
To use CrateDB with Python, you can refer to the official CrateDB Python driver documentation which provides examples on how to interact with CrateDB using different interfaces like DB API, HTTP, and BLOB. You can find the documentation [here](https://cratedb.com/docs/python/en/latest/by-example/index.html#by-example).

Additionally, you can explore the `cratedb-examples` repository which contains executable code examples demonstrating the use of the driver for different applications like a guestbook application, using CrateDB with pandas, Apache Superset, and FIWARE QuantumLeap data historian projects. The repository and corresponding documentation can be found [here](https://cratedb.com/docs/python/en/latest/).

examples.input_text: how to alter table and add fulltext index?
examples.output_text_a:
To alter a table and add a full-text index in CrateDB, you can use the `ALTER TABLE` statement along with the `ADD INDEX` clause. Here is an example of how you can achieve this:

```sql
ALTER TABLE your_table_name
ADD INDEX your_column_name_ft USING FULLTEXT(your_column_name) WITH (analyzer = 'english');
```

Make sure to replace `your_table_name` with the actual name of your table and `your_column_name` with the column for which you want to add the full-text index.

For more information on fulltext indices in CrateDB, you can refer to the official documentation [here](https://cratedb.com/docs/crate/reference/en/master/general/ddl/fulltext-indices.html).
examples.output_text_b:
To alter a table and add a fulltext index in CrateDB, you can follow the syntax provided in the documentation:

1. Define the table:
   ```
   cr> create table table_f (
   ...   first_column text,
   ... );
   ```

2. Add a fulltext index to the specified column:
   ```
   cr> alter table table_f add index first_column_ft
   ... using fulltext(first_column) with (analyzer = 'english');
   ```
   
   For further information and detailed steps, you can refer to the [CrateDB documentation](https://cratedb.com/docs/crate/reference/en/master/general/ddl/fulltext-indices.html).

examples.input_text: how to alter table and add vector type field that allows for KNN search?
examples.output_text_a:
To alter a table and add a vector type field that allows for KNN search in CrateDB, you can follow the steps outlined in the official documentation:

1. Create a table with vector data type:
   ```sql
   CREATE TABLE my_data (
     xs FLOAT_VECTOR(2)
   );
   ```

2. Insert values into the table:
   ```sql
   INSERT INTO my_data VALUES ([1.6,2.7]), ([4.6, 7.8]);
   ```

3. The `FLOAT_VECTOR` type in CrateDB allows you to store dense vectors of float values of fixed length and supports KNN_MATCH for k-nearest neighbor search. This enables you to find vectors in a dataset that are similar to a query vector.

You can refer to the source for more information: [CrateDB Documentation - Data Types](https://cratedb.com/docs/crate/reference/en/master/general/ddl/data-types.html)

examples.input_text: create table with fields ID, name, vector, and index vector field for KNN search?
examples.output_text_a:
To create a table with fields ID, name, vector, and index the vector field for KNN search, you can use the following SQL query:

```sql
CREATE TABLE my_table (
  ID INTEGER PRIMARY KEY,
  name TEXT,
  vector FLOAT_VECTOR(2),
  INDEX vector_Idx USING GIN (vector) WITH (fastupdate='off')
);
```

This query creates a table called `my_table` with the specified fields and creates an index on the `vector` field to optimize KNN search operations.

Source: [CrateDB Documentation](https://cratedb.com/docs/crate/reference/en/master/sql/statements/create-index.html)
examples.output_text_b:
To create a table with fields ID, name, vector, and index vector field for KNN search, you can use the following SQL commands:

```sql
CREATE TABLE my_table (
   ID INTEGER,
   name TEXT,
   vector FLOAT_VECTOR(2),
   INDEX my_vector_index USING KNN (vector) WITH (dimension = 2)
);
```

This SQL statement will create a table named `my_table` with the specified fields and an index on the `vector` field optimized for KNN searches.

Sources:
- [CrateDB Blog - Unlocking the Power of Vector Support and KNN Search in CrateDB](https://cratedb.com/blog/unlocking-the-power-of-vector-support-and-knn-search-in-cratedb)
- [CrateDB Documentation - Data Types](https://cratedb.com/docs/crate/reference/en/master/general/ddl/data-types.html)

examples.input_text: What are the benefits of using CrateDB?
examples.output_text_a:
The benefits of using CrateDB include high performance, scalability, flexibility, horizontal scalability, multi-model database engine support, multi-platform support, simplified data infrastructure, real-time data updates, native SQL query language, efficient management of concurrent reads and writes, reduced total cost of ownership (TCO), data synchronization, support for AI/ML, fully distributed query engine, columnar storage for fast data access, ad-hoc queries across billions of records in milliseconds, hyper-fast aggregations, in-memory SQL query performance, high-performance distributed query engine, support for dynamic schemas, queryable objects, time-series data, real-time full-text search, and a powerful REST API for programmable interface management. 

Sources:

examples.input_text: Does index creation block write operations?
examples.output_text_a:
Based on the provided context, index creation does not block write operations. The blocking of write operations would occur if the `write.wait_for_active_shards` setting is configured a certain way and a node is stopped during the write operation. The write operations would then block until the replica is fully replicated again or timeout if the replication is not fast enough. 

Source: [CrateDB Documentation](https://cratedb.com/docs/crate/reference/en/5.6/sql/statements/create-table.html)

examples.input_text: How to do fusion search and connect vector search with fulltext search
examples.output_text_a: To perform fusion search and connect vector search with full-text search, you can utilize the advanced search capabilities offered by CrateDB. By combining vector, full-text, and keyword searches, you can achieve improved semantic similarity and keyword matching, enhancing search precision and relevance. This integration of different search techniques allows for a more comprehensive and efficient search experience. For more information, you can refer to the source [here](https://cratedb.com/solutions/vector-database).
